Studies on removal of Pb(II) and Cr(III) using graphene oxide based inverse spinel nickel ferrite nano-composite as sorbent

Synthesis of a hybrid graphene oxide based inverse spinel nickel ferrite (GONF) nano-composite material and subsequent utilization in heavy metal removal from aqueous solution is described in the present study. The synthesized GONF was characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform-infrared resonance (FT-IR), and X-ray photoelectron (XPS) spectroscopies. The morphology, the surface area and pore volume of GONF were evaluated by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and BET analysis, respectively. GONF was successfully used for the removal of Pb(II) and Cr(III) by batch adsorption techniques. Batch kinetics studies revealed that the sorption of Pb(II) and Cr(III) onto GONFwaswell described by a pseudo-second-order equation. The sorption equilibrium data of Pb(II) and Cr(III) was well tuned to the Langmuir isotherm model than the Freundlich and Temkin isothermmodels. Hence, the sorption of Pb(II) and Cr(III) onto GONF occurred throughmonolayer chemisorptions on the homogeneous surface of GONF. The pH sorption results suggest that the sorption occurs through a complexed mechanism. The sorption of metal ions increased with increasing temperature, which is evident for an endothermic chemisorption by inner-sphere surface complexation. The overall obtained results demonstrated the GONF as an effective sorbent for Pb(II) and Cr(III) removal from wastewater.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Heavy metals are one of the major contaminates in water pollution. Exposure to heavy metals, even at trace levels, is believed to be a high health risk for humans. The typical heavy metals, such as Pb(II) and Cr(III), in aqueous solutions are more toxic even at trace levels and have caused adverse health impacts on human beings (Bagchi et al., 2002; Koduru and Lee, 2014; Poreba et al., 2011; Reddy and Lee, 2013a; Roh et al., 2015; Wang et al., 1997). Hence removal of these heavy metals from aqueous environment is of the utmost importance to protect biodiversity, hydrosphere ecosystems, and human beings. Conventional methodologies have been applied for removal of these heavy metals from aqueous environment via chemical precipitation, ion exchange, membrane filtration and biological treatment, etc. (Fu and Wang, 2011; Sud et al., 2008). However, the sorption process has to be an effective and efficient technique for treatment of heavy metals from water with easy handling and availability of a wide range of adsorbents (Koduru et al., 2013; Koduru et al., 2014; Lingamdinne

et al., 2015a, 2015b; Roh et al., 2015; Oraby and Eksteen, 2015). But, some difficulties are faced in the filtration and regeneration of adsorbent for their subsequent applications and to overcome these difficulties, novel sorbents designs are necessary. In the recent years, magnetic materials have been widely used as an adsorbent for treatment of toxic contaminates (Koduru et al., 2013; Reddy and Lee, 2013a, 2013b). Moreover, magnetite metal oxides or various ferrites are frequently used in the hydrometallurgical extraction process for recovery of precious metals (Ranjbar et al., 2014) and heavy metals (Muravyov et al., 2012; Zhao et al., 2013), and regulating digestion of high silica bauxite (Li et al., 2010). Among the available magnetic sorbents, inorganic spinel ferrites and their composite materials were widely used inwater treatment due to its unique advantages ofmagnetic and chemical stability (Deraz et al., 2010; Hou et al., 2010; Lv et al., 2009; Ren et al., 2012).
However, the inverse spinel nickel ferrite (NiFe2O4) was the most significant due to ferromagnetic momentum originating, from antiparallel spins between Fe3+ and Ni2+ at tetrahedral and octahedral sites, respectively (Kinemuchi et al., 2002). And this material has been used in gas-sensor, magnetic fluids, catalysis, magnetic storage systems, photo magnetic materials, magnetic resonance imaging, site-specific drug delivery and microwave devices (Chu et al., 2007; Galindo et al., 2012; Giri et al., 2000; Hasmonay et al., 2000; Raikher et al., 2004;
(II) and Cr(III) using graphene oxide based inverse spinel nickel ferrite .1016/j.hydromet.2015.11.005
Rana et al., 2005; Son et al., 2002). Moreover,metal ferrites exhibit a porous structure with a high internal specific surface area, magnetic response, good chemical stability and high sorption capacity (Agrawal and Sahu, 2006; Li et al., 2011; White et al., 2009; Xu et al., 2009; Vanbenschoten et al., 1994). However, as the size of metal oxides reduces frommicrometer to nanometer levels, the increased surface energy inevitably leads to poor stability (Maaz et al., 2009). In order to overcome these difficulties, the hydrothermal co-precipitation method has been used for synthesis of inverse spinel NiF2O4 with graphene oxide as precursor. Recently, some researchers are using the modified magnetic-carbon composites (Condomitti et al., 2014; Park et al., 2015) and magnetic organic composites (Aliakbari et al., 2014; Koduru et al., 2013) in the hydrometallurgical process for the removal and separation of precious metals.
Graphene, a single two-dimensional (2D) layer of carbon atoms and oxide form, graphene oxide (GO), have large specific surface areas and good biocompatibility. And commonly GO was synthesized by the Hummers method. Most of the graphene oxide usually has functional groups, such as hydroxyl and carboxyl, advantageous for adsorbing heavymetal ions (Li et al., 2009).Magnetic graphene oxide andmagnetic graphene composites or graphene based nanomaterials (Chen et al., 2011) have been fabricated and they have shown good properties for drug delivery (Chen et al., 2010), energy storage (Zhang et al., 2010), and water treatment (Chandra et al., 2010; Koo et al., 2011; Xu et al., 2009). In this study, synthesizedGO basedmagnetic inverse spinel nickel ferrite (GONF)material by the chemical co-precipitationmethodwas used for the treatment of Pb(II) and Cr(III) from aqueous solutions by batch sorption studies. The batch sorption results demonstrated the GONF to be a promising, economic and easily recoverable sorbent for the treatment of heavy metals from hydrometallurgical industries.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: All chemicals were of analytical reagent grade and used as supplied. Graphite flakes were supplied from Sigma Aldrich (USA). Pb(NO3)2, Cr(NO3)3·9H2O, Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, Ni(NO3)3·9H2O, HCl (40%), NH4OH (56.6%) andH2SO4 (98%)were supplied by the Samchun Pure Chemicals Co. Ltd. (Korea). KMnO4 and NaOH (98%) were purchased from Kanto Chemical Co. Inc. (Japan). NaNO3 (98%) was purchased from Duksan Pure Chemicals (Korea). H2O2 (30%) was supplied by Junsei Chemicals Co. Ltd. (Japan).

sections.heading: 2.2. Synthesis of graphene oxide based inverse spinel nickel ferrite (GONF) nano-composite
sections.text:
Graphene oxide (GO) prepared from oxidation of graphite flakes by the Hummers method (Hummers and Offeman, 1958) was used for the synthesis of graphene oxide based spinel nickel ferrite (GONF) (Scheme 1). First, 1.0 g GO was dispersed in 1000 mL double distilled de-ionized (DDDI) water by agitating with ultrasonication for 1 h.
Scheme 1. Schematic representation of the prep

Then, 5.0 g Fe(NO3)3·9H2O and 1.75 g Ni(NO3)3·9H2O (2:1 molar ratio of Fe3+: Ni2+) were dissolved in 100 mL of DDDI water. This solutionwas added dropwise to GO solution at room temperature with vigorous stirring. After completing ion exchange, the pH of the solution wasmonitored and adjusted with drop wise addition of NaOH solution. The reactantswere vigorously stirred using amagnetic stirrer until a pH level of N12 was achieved. Then the solution was kept at 80 °C for 45 min with continuously stirring, resulting a black precipitate in solution. Finally, it was cooled to room temperature, and washed several times with de-ionized water, dried at 60 °C under vacuum for 12 h. The characteristics of the final product were identified by XRD, FT-IR, MPMS, andXPS, asmagnetic graphene oxide based inverse spinel nickel ferrite nano-composite (GO@NiFe2O4) (GONF).

sections.heading: 2.3. Characterization of GONF nano-composite
sections.text: The crystalline structure of GONF nano-compositematerialwas confirmed by XRD analysis using a Rigaku D/Max-2500 X-ray diffractometer (Japan). Spectrum GX & Auto image FT-IR (Perkin-Elmer, USA) was used for analyzing functional groups of GONF. ESCALAB-210 (Spain) X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used for elemental analysis of the prepared GONF and samples. AMastersizer-3000 (UK) particle size analyzer was used to measure the particle size of GONF. S-4300 & EDX-350 (Hitachi, Japan) were used for measuring surface morphology and composition. An Autosorb-1, Quantachrome instrument (USA) was used to measure the BET surface area and pore sizes of GONF. Veeco Inc., (New York) atomic force microscope (AFM) imaging was used to make AFM-images. A Sonics Vibracell (CV 334, USA) was used for ultrasonification of GO and GONF. Magnetic measurements were done using a SQUID magnetometer (MPMS-7, Quantum Design, USA).

sections.heading: 2.4. Batch sorption experiments
sections.text:
The stock solution (1000 mg/L) of metal ions, Pb(II) and Cr(III), was prepared from Pb(NO3)2 and Cr(NO3)3·9H2O. A typical batch sorption experiment was carried out with 40 mL of aqueous solution of Pb(II) and Cr(III) with a known initial concentration at pH 5.5 for Pb(II) and pH 4.0 for Cr(III) in a Falcon tube at room temperature. 0.75 g/L (for Pb(II)) and 0.5 g/L (for Cr(III)) of GONF were added to the above mentioned solution. Then, themixturewas shaken for pre-determined equilibrium time intervals (120 min), and the samples were filtered out through a 0.45 μm membrane syringe filter for measuring the metal ion concentration using an Optima 2100 DV inductive coupled plasma–optical emission spectrometer (ICP–OES) (Perkin-Elmer, USA). The amount of Pb(II) and Cr(III) adsorbed onto GONF was calculated from the mass balance between the initial (Co) and equilibrium (Ce) concentrations (mg/L) of metal ions. The metal uptake capacity (qe, mg/g) of GONF was calculated by the following equation:

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization of GONF nano-composite material
sections.text:
The XRD analysis confirmed the crystalline properties and the formation of GO and GONF (Fig. 1). The prepared GO showed a strong peak at 2θ = 11.3° indicating the formation of GO (Fan et al., 2010; Marcano et al., 2010; Song et al., 2014), and shifted to 8.9° in GONF. The peaks at 2θ = 26.6°, 36.65° and 45° in GONF indicate the presence of inverse spinel magnetic nickel ferrite and were in good agreement with the literature (Maaz et al., 2009; Nejati and Zabihi, 2012; Senthilkumar et al., 2011). The overall XRD results proved the formation of the GO based crystalline nature of cubic inverse spinel nickel ferrite (GONF).
X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) studies confirmed the end product, GONF (Fig. 2). The high binding energy intensities of O (1s), and Fe (2p) and Ni (2p) peaks indicate the formation of GO and GONF. The shifting of O (1s) binding energy to lower range by the loading of spinel NiFe2O4 onto GO, indicates the formation GONF. Further, FT-IR spectrum studies of GO and GONF (Fig. 3) indicated the presence of various functional groups. The sharp peaks around 1412 cm−1–1500 cm−1 indicated the asymmetric –C–C_C– stretching vibration at aromatic
Please cite this article as: Lingamdinne, L.P., et al., Studies on removal of Pb nano-composite as sorbent, Hydrometallurgy (2015), http://dx.doi.org/10
alkenes or H–C–H bending vibrations in alkanes of aromatic ring. The peaks at 1300 cm−1–1000 cm−1 indicated the –C–O stretching vibrations of epoxy and alkoxy groups in ester or ethers. The broad peaks around 3017 cm−1–3173 cm−1 were assigned to the hydrogen bond of –OHgroups on aromatic phenol, alcohol or carboxylic acids. The overall results of the FT-IR spectrum confirmed the formation of GO from graphite (Fan et al., 2010; Marcano et al., 2010; Song et al., 2014). The shifting of absorption peaks at higher wavelengths in the FT-IR spectrum of GONF is associated with the formation of GONF from GO. The inset figures of the FT-IR spectrum indicate the Fe–O vibration bonds of ferrites. The sharp peaks at 400 cm−1–550 cm−1 indicated the tetrahedral and octahedral Fe–O bonds (Maaz et al., 2009; Nejati and Zabihi, 2012; Senthilkumar et al., 2011). From the above preceding results, the formation of inverse spinel nickel ferrite–graphene oxide composite was confirmed.

The surfacemorphology of GONFwas different from GO, showing dark shiny morphology and confirming the formation of GONF. The BET analysis of GONFwas used tomeasure the surface area, pore volume, particle size, and diameter. The BET surface area of GONF (136 m2/g) with a 199 m2/g Langmuir surface area was more than the GO (2.80m2/g) surface area, indicating the impregnation of inverse spinel cubic NiFe2O4 into GO and formation of end product, GONF.

The magnetic hysteresis curve (M–H) of the nano-magnetic GONF composite was recorded at 300 K and was shown in Fig.6a. These M–H hysteresis curve results revealed the resultant magnetic property of GONF to be superparamagnetic. From Fig.6a, the saturated magnetization (Ms), remnant magnetization (Mr), coercivity (Hc), and squareness (Sr=Mr./Ms) were calculated to be 41.34 emu/g, 5.0 emu/g, 734Oe, and 8.268, respectively. The paramagnetic property of GONF was also confirmed from magnetic susceptibility (χ) determined to be +1.8 × 10−3 emu/cm3 Oe, from the slope of theM–H curve. The small saturation magnetization of resultant GONF particles than bulk NiFe2O4 is due to the presence of GO and the smaller size of NiFe2O4 nano-particles (Chandra et al., 2010). Another possible reason is the electron exchange between the nickel ferrite andGO and accompanying quenching of the magnetic momentum by surface atoms. The decrease in the Ms. value for the resultant GONF compared to NiFe2O4 is reasonable (Chen and Wu, 2000; Liao and Chen, 2002; Vanleeuwen et al., 1994). The GONF dispersed in water was magnetically separated by an external magnetic field as shown in Fig. 6b. The separation was completed in less than 10 s in the applied magnetic field of ~20 mT.

sections.heading: 3.2. Sorption studies of Pb(II) and Cr(III) onto GONF nano-composite material
3.2.1. Effect of pH and ionic strength
sections.text:
Aqueous solution pH was the most important factor influencing the sorption ofmetal ions by the change of surface properties of sorbent and formation of variousmetal ion species in aqueous solution. The effects of solution pH on the adsorption of Pb(II) and Cr(III) onto GONF were studied by varying the pH (Fig. 7a). The sorption of Pb(II) and Cr(III) rapidly increased from pH 2.0 to 3.0, then slowly increased and reached
Please cite this article as: Lingamdinne, L.P., et al., Studies on removal of Pb nano-composite as sorbent, Hydrometallurgy (2015), http://dx.doi.org/10
maximum sorption percentage at pH 5.0 to 6.0 for Pb(II). While the sorption of Cr(III) was not much increased pH N 3.0. The competitive sorption of metal ions and more positive H+ ions on active sites of GONF at lower pH may cause lower sorption. As the solution pH increased, the sorption of metal ions on the GONF increased and demonstrated in an acid dissociation constant (pKa = 5.1). Above pH 5.0, the surface charges of GONF became more negative and caused increased sorption of metal ions. Sorption experiments were not studied above pH 6.0 where the metal ions can be precipitate as their hydroxide complexes.Most of the Pb(II) or Cr(III) sorption ontoGONFwas started from pH 3.0. The 85% and 98% sorption percentages were achieved at pH 3.0 for Pb(II) and Cr(III), respectively. While 93% and 99.6% sorption percentages were achieved at pH 6.0 for Pb(II) and pH 4.0 for Cr(III), respectively. This result suggests that the sorption occurs through outersphere surface complexation at lower pH (b3.0) and an inner-sphere surface complexation at higher pH (N3.0) for both metal ions (Reddy and Lee, 2013a; Ruyter-Hooley et al., 2015; Srivastava et al., 2015). Cr(III) sorption was high at pH 3.0–5.0, where available free Cr(III) and positive chromium hydroxide ions (CrOH+2, Cr2(OH)4+4 and Cr3(OH)4+5) are favorable for adsorption on the negative surface of the adsorbent. However, Cr(III) sorption was decreasing slightly above pH 5.0 but not significant, it may be decreasing the available free Cr(III), CrOH+2 Cr2(OH)4+4 and Cr3(OH)4+5 species by complete conversion as Cr(OH)3(S) (Electronic supplementary materials (ESM): Fig. S1). While Pb(II) converted as PbOH+ and Pb2OH3+ at above pH 6.0, which was confirmed from an illustration obtained from Visual Minteq-3.0 (ESM: Fig. S1). And also at pH N5.5, both metal ions started to precipitate. Based on the pH effect results, further batch sorption was studied at pH 5.5 for Pb(II) and pH 4.0 for Cr(III). sections.heading: 3.2.2. Dosage effect
sections.text: The sorbent dosage was a very important factor influencing the sorption of metal ions. The effect of adsorbent dosage on the sorption of Pb(II) and Cr(III) (10 mg/L) was studied by varying dosage from 0.125 to 2.5 g/L at pH 5.5 for Pb(II) and pH 4.0 for Cr(III). The obtained results (Fig. 7b) revealed the adsorption efficiency and adsorption capacity showed an inverse relationship with GONF dose. This trend is similar to that in a study reported elsewhere (Koduru et al., 2013). Metal ion uptake percentage onto GONF increased from 80% to 93% for Pb(II) and 40% to 99.6% for Cr(III) whereas the adsorption capacity decreased from 85 to 5.0 mg/g for Pb(II) and 38 to 5.6 mg/g for Cr(III). The maximum sorption efficiency, 93% for Pb(II) and 99.6% Cr(III), was achievedwith 0.75 g/L and 0.5 g/L GONFdosage for Pb(II) and Cr(III), respectively. Further studies were carried out with 0.75 g/L for Pb(II) and 0.5 g/L for Cr(III) GONF dosage.

sections.heading: 3.2.3. Effect of contact time and the sorption kinetics
sections.text:
Fig. 8 shows that the removal of Pb(II) and Cr(III) increased as the contact time increased. However, equilibrium of Pb(II) and Cr(III) was attained in 60 min and 120 min, respectively. As contact time further
increased to 24 h, the sorption percentage becomes constant. Therefore, the contact time can be optimized to 120min for both Pb(II) and Cr(III). K1 (min−1) and K2 (g/mg·min), pseudo-first-order and second-order sorption rate constants were obtained from respective linear curve slopes of Eqs. (2) and (3) (ESM: Fig. S2). The obtained kinetic parameters were summarized in Table 1. The suitability of the kinetic models was evaluated by the linear correlation coefficient (R2) and the sorption capacities (qe) obtained experimentally and by calculation. The higher R2 and closeness of qe values with lower standard deviations suggest that the pseudo-second-order kinetics was well tuned with the experimental kinetic data. These obtained results conclude that the sorption kinetics of Pb(II) and Cr(III) onto GONF was rate limiting pseudosecond-order.

The calculated isotherm parameters, correlation coefficient (R2) values and standard deviations in measurement were used for the evaluation of suitability of isotherms and were summarized in Table 2. The Langmuir isotherm model was in line with the sorption equilibrium data compared to the other two models. Additionally, the Langmuir isotherm dimensionless separation factor RL (Koduru et al., 2013) values were confirmed to be 0 b RL b 1, and are summarized in Table 2. Hence, the sorption of Pb(II) and Cr(III) onto GONF was monolayer chemisorptions on the homogeneous surface. The sorption capacity of GONF was greater than that of GO-alone due to the high electron transfer charge of GONF by NiFe3O4 (Reddy and Lee, 2013a). The maximum sorption capacity of GONF at 298 ± 2 K for Pb(II) (25.0 mg/g) and Cr(III) (45.5 mg/g) was higher or near to reported values indicating GONF to be a promising and better sorbent for heavy metal sorption from hydrometallurgical industries.
The distribution of Pb(II) and Cr(III) between GONF and solution in equilibrium over a range of concentrations at three different temperatures (298–328 K) was studied. To the obtained isotherm results applied the Langmuir isotherm model and calculated maximum sorption capacities (qmax) were increased as increasing temperature from 298 to 328 K for both metal ions and the results shown in Table 3. From the results obtained maximum sorption capacities, 25.0, 37.03 and 46.03 mg/g for Pb(II) and 45.50, 56.18 and 64.10 mg/g for Cr(III) indicate the chemical interactions between sorbate and sorbent (Lingamdinne et al., 2015a, 2015b; Reddy and Lee, 2013a; RuyterHooley et al., 2015).

sections.heading: 3.2.5. Evaluation of Pb(II) and Cr(III) sorption mechanism onto GONF
sections.text:
The FT-IR spectrum (Fig. 3) of GONF loaded with heavy metal ions was also studied for explanation of sorption mechanism. Shifting of absorption peaks of –C–O,−C–C_C– and –OH functional groups of GONF to lower wavelength by loading Pb(II) and Cr(III) was observed as well as shifting of Fe–O (insert of Fig. 3) bond stretching vibration peaks to lower wavelength range. This shifting was due to the sorption of Pb(II) and Cr(III) onto GONF and suggests the chemical interaction between metal ions and GONF surface functional groups such as –C–O, −C–C_C– and –OH along with oxygen in the Fe–O bond of ferrite.
The SEM-morphology (Fig. 4) studies also confirmed themetal ion loading onto GONF. The surface morphology of metal ion loaded GONF was different to bare GONF, indicating Pb(II) and Cr(III) sorption onto GONF. The overall obtained results described chemical interactions or complexed surface interactions between homogeneous surface functional groups of GONF and metal ions causing chemisorption. Hence, the synthesized GONF could be justified as an efficient sorbent and reasonable for the treatment of heavy metals. In addition, GONF can be easily separated by an external magnetic field without loss of any structural changes and can be reused. The schematic representation of sorption of Pb(II) and Cr(III) onto GONF is shown in Scheme 2.

sections.heading: 3.2.6. Regeneration and reuse of GONF
sections.text: The stability and reusability of GONF were investigated by adsorption and desorption of Pb(II) and Cr(III) onto GONF. Each metal ion (10mg/L= Pb(II) and Cr(III)) loaded GONFwas recovered by an external magnetic field and treated with pH 1.0 (HNO3 acid) aqueous solution at each cycle. The sorption capacity of the regenerated GONF is shown in Fig. 10. It can be found that the sorption capacity of GONF for both metal ions is stable within three cycles, then after decreasing, indicating that GONF can be reused up to three cycles repeatedly. It may be destroying the surface of GONF by dissolving some of nickel ferrite particles, if you use more than three cycles. The desorption capacities of GONF were also good up to four cycles with more than 95%, then after it was decreasing less than 80% for Pb(II) and Cr(III).

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
The synthesized graphene oxide based porous inverse spinel nickel ferrite (GONF) was confirmed by instrument techniques of the XRD, FT-IR, and XPS studies. The characterization results confirmed the formation of mesoporous nano-crystalline cubic inverse spinel nickel ferrite–graphene oxide (GONF). The SEM and BET analysis were also performed to evaluate the surfacemorphology, surface area and particle size of GONF. These results concluded the formation of GONFwith dark shiny porous surface morphology having a 136 m2/g BET surface area with a 199 m2/g Langmuir surface area. In order to evaluate sorption characteristics of GONF, removal of Pb(II) and Cr(III) was studied by batch sorption studies. XRD, BET and AFM studies concluded that the size of GONF was ~40 nm. The positive magnetic susceptibility (χ) determined, +1.8 × 10−3 emu/cm3 Oe from the slope of the M–H curve confirmed the paramagnetic property of GONF. These sorption studies concluded that the sorption of Pb(II) and Cr(III) was monolayer chemisorptions on the homogeneous surface of GONF with rate limiting pseudo-second-order kinetics. metadata.abstractText: Article history: Received 22 May 2015 Received in revised form 26 October 2015 Accepted 11 November 2015 Available online xxxx Synthesis of a hybrid graphene oxide based inverse spinel nickel ferrite (GONF) nano-composite material and subsequent utilization in heavy metal removal from aqueous solution is described in the present study. The synthesized GONF was characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform-infrared resonance (FT-IR), and X-ray photoelectron (XPS) spectroscopies. The morphology, the surface area and pore volume of GONF were evaluated by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and BET analysis, respectively. GONF was successfully used for the removal of Pb(II) and Cr(III) by batch adsorption techniques. Batch kinetics studies revealed that the sorption of Pb(II) and Cr(III) onto GONFwaswell described by a pseudo-second-order equation. The sorption equilibrium data of Pb(II) and Cr(III) was well tuned to the Langmuir isotherm model than the Freundlich and Temkin isothermmodels. Hence, the sorption of Pb(II) and Cr(III) onto GONF occurred throughmonolayer chemisorptions on the homogeneous surface of GONF. The pH sorption results suggest that the sorption occurs through a complexed mechanism. The sorption of metal ions increased with increasing temperature, which is evident for an endothermic chemisorption by inner-sphere surface complexation. The overall obtained results demonstrated the GONF as an effective sorbent for Pb(II) and Cr(III) removal from wastewater. © 2015 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
